publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: they have been invited. After the meal, Buddha gathered the community, and blamed this affair. The monk should not sit or lie on a mat belonging to the monastery without extention.
Nach dem Essen versammelte der Buddha die Gemeinde.
After the meal, the Buddha assembled the community.
He ordered to prepare a bed-roll. || Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. In the morning, he carried his alms-bowl and clothes and entered into Śrāvastī for the alms.

Am Morgen nahm er [scil. der Buddha] Almosenschale [und] Gewand [und] trat in Śrāvastī den Almosen[gang] an. Nach dem Essen nahm er seine Sitzmatte [und] ging in den Andhava-Wald, um in Meditation zu sitzen.

In the morning, he [i.e. the Buddha] took [his] alms bowl [and] robe [and] began his alms [round] in Śrāvastī. After [his] meal, he took his sitting mat [and] went into the Andhava forest to sit in meditation.
After the meal, he carried a sitting-mat and went to the forest Andhavana in order to sit in meditation. The venerable Kāḷodāyin followed Buddha.
Buddha extended the sitting-mat under some tree and sat. Kāḷodāyin also extended the sitting-mat under some other tree through pressing against and

Der Buddha breitete sich [seine] Sitzmatte unter einem [wtl. irgendeinem] Baum aus [und] setzte sich. Auch Kāḷodāyin breitete sich [seine] Sitzmatte von gleicher Größe(?) unter einem [wtl. irgendeinem] Baum aus [und] setzte sich.

The Buddha spread out [his] sitting mat for himself under a [lit. any, some] tree [and] seated himself. Kāḷodāyin, too, spread out [his] sitting mat of equal size(?) for himself under a [lit. any, some] tree [and] seated himself.
sat. His body was big and both of his knees touched the earth. Then, he said, 'Oh! Buddha should order to add one span from the fringe
Then he said, «Oh!, may the Buddha order to make the sitting-mat one span larger from the fringe!»
in (every) directions (to the size of) the sitting-mat.' || If a monk makes a sitting-mat, it should be made according to the measure. Here is the measure:
There is that measure: in length two spans according to the Buddha span, crosswise one and a half, [and] one span for the fringes. If he makes [it] more than that, [it is] a pātayantika offence.

Bei einer Sitzgelegenheit [ist] von dem Mönch, der [sie] anfertigt, nach Maß zu verfahren. Hier [wtl. da] ist das Maß: In der Länge zwei Spannen entsprechend der Spanne des Buddha, in der Breite anderthalb [Spannen] für die Fransen eine Spanne. Macht er mehr als das, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika-Vergehen.

With seating, it must be made by the monk who makes it according to measure. There is the measure: in length, two spans corresponding to the span of the Buddha, in breadth one and a half [spans] for the fringe one span. If he makes more than that, [this is] a Pātayantika offence.
two spans in length according to the span of Buddha, in width one span with half from the fringe. If he makes it more than that, Pāt. || Buddha
was staying in Kapilavastu. If a Buddha's brother, named Nanda, enters into the community, a half of the monks were doubtful, 'Is it Buddha or Nanda who entered?'
Nanda lacked two marks of Buddha, and he lacked four fingers from Buddha. He made for himself the clothes
Er [scil. Nanda] machte sich ein dem Gewand des Buddha gleiches Gewand.
He [i.e. Nanda] made for himself a garment alike to the Buddha's garment.
Er machte sich ein dem Gewand des Buddha gleiches Gewand.
He made for himself a robe alike to that of the Buddha.
which was similar to that of Buddha. Buddha heard and gathered the community. He proclaimed the prescription. || If a monk
Which monk would make a garment according to the measure of the garment of the Buddha, or exceeding the Buddha garment—pātayantika.
Wenn sich aber ein Mönch [wtl. welcher Mönch] ein Gewand nach dem Maß des Gewandes des Buddha oder über das Buddhagewand hinaus macht, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika[-Vergehen].
If, however a monk [lit. which[ever] monk] makes for himself a garment according to the measure of the Buddha's garment, or beyond the Buddha's garment, [this is] a Pātayantika [offence].
makes the clothes according to the size of the clothes of Buddha, or more than that of the clothes of Buddha, Pāt. Here is the size of the clothes of Buddha:
nine spans in length according to the span of Buddha, six spans in width. This is the size of the clothes of Buddha. 90 ||

p.note: A parallel text is found in , cf. also .
According to 70, "in a very good state of preservation. Written in medium sized ductus".

list.item: a1 they have been invited. After the meal, Buddha gathered the community, and blamed this affair. The monk should not sit or lie on a mat belonging to the monastery without extention. a2 He ordered to prepare a bed-roll. || Buddha was staying in Śrāvastī. In the morning, he carried his alms-bowl and clothes and entered into Śrāvastī for the alms. a3 After the meal, he carried a sitting-mat and went to the forest Andhavana in order to sit in meditation. The venerable Kāḷodāyin followed Buddha. a4 Buddha extended the sitting-mat under some tree and sat. Kāḷodāyin also extended the sitting-mat under some other tree through pressing against and a5 sat. His body was big and both of his knees touched the earth. Then, he said, 'Oh! Buddha should order to add one span from the fringe a6 in (every) directions (to the size of) the sitting-mat.' || If a monk makes a sitting-mat, it should be made according to the measure. Here is the measure: b1 two spans in length according to the span of Buddha, in width one span with half from the fringe. If he makes it more than that, Pāt. || Buddha b2 was staying in Kapilavastu. If a Buddha's brother, named Nanda, enters into the community, a half of the monks were doubtful, 'Is it Buddha or Nanda who entered?' b3 Nanda lacked two marks of Buddha, and he lacked four fingers from Buddha. He made for himself the clothes b4 which was similar to that of Buddha. Buddha heard and gathered the community. He proclaimed the prescription. || If a monk b5 makes the clothes according to the size of the clothes of Buddha, or more than that of the clothes of Buddha, Pāt. Here is the size of the clothes of Buddha: b6 nine spans in length according to the span of Buddha, six spans in width. This is the size of the clothes of Buddha. 90 ||

a1 (ka)kākauwa • śeśuwer postäṃ pañäkte sāṅk|sāṅ kraupāte • cau|ce_u wäntare nāksate (•) s(a)ṅkik raktsisa ṣam(ā)nentse • eñatketse m(ā) ceppi(l)l(e) a2 mā wsaṣṣälle • prastrāṃ yātka yāmtsi • || pañäkte śrāvastine mäskīträ • tsoṅkaik pātrai wastsi kamāte śrāvastine pintwāt|piṃtwāt yopsa • a3 śeśuwer postäṃ • niṣīdaṃ kamāte andhavaṃ warttone masa ompalskoññe lamatsi • śaulassu kāḷodāye pañäkte ompostäṃ|o|mpostäṃ a4 masa • pañäkte alyek|alyekä kca stām ñor niṣīdaṃ raksate lyama • kāḷodāye rano alyek|alyekä kca stām ñor oppīläṃntsa|oppīläṃ|ntsa a5 niṣīdaṃ raksate lyama • su no orotstse|orotse kektseñtsa|kektsentsa • antapi kenisa|kenīsa keṃ teksa • tumeṃ weña au • watkaṣṣi pi pañäkte niṣīdaṃ a6 ñremeṃ kalymi|kälymi raso tsamtsi • || lamallesa ṣamānentsa yamaskemanesa • yärmaṃssu yamaṣṣälle|yamaṣälle • omte se yarm|yarmä pärkarñesa|pärkarñe|sa b1 wi rsoñcä • pañäktentse rasosa • pkantesa śle ywārc|ywārcä • ñrets raso • tumeṃ oṃṣap yāmtär|yāmträ • īpäṣṣeñca || || pañäkte kapilavāstune|kapilavā|stune b2 mäskīträ • pañäktentse procer nānde ñem • kwri|kr_ui sāṅkne|sāṅne yapi sklokacci ṣamāni ywārc|ywārcä mäskīyenträ • pañäkte wat yopsa b3 nānde wat • wi lakṣānäñcä • pañäktemeṃ nandentse meṅki ṣeṃ • śtwāra praroṃ pañäktemeṃ meṅki ṣai • pañäktentse wastsimpa|wastsi|mpa b4 sām • wastsi yamaṣṣiträ • pañäkte klyauṣa sāṅk|sāṅ kraupāte • ce śikṣapāt śānmya • || mäksu no ṣamāne • pañäktentse b5 wästsintse yarmtsa wastsi yamīträ • oṃṣap|oṃṣṣap wat pañäktäññe wästsimeṃ • īpäṣṣeñca • omte te pañäktentse wästsintse yarm|yarmä • b6 pärkarññesa ñu rsonta • pañäktäññe rasosa • pkantesa ṣkas • te om(t)e pañäktentse wästsintse yarm|yarmä • 90 || weweñuwa ñä(ssa)

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]

a5-6 Then he said, «Oh!, may the Buddha order to make the sitting-mat one span larger from the fringe!» 361
a6-b1 There is that measure: in length two spans according to the Buddha span, crosswise one and a half, [and] one span for the fringes. If he makes [it] more than that, [it is] a pātayantika offence. 318
b4-5 Which monk would make a garment according to the measure of the garment of the Buddha, or exceeding the Buddha garment—pātayantika. 335


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1 Nach dem Essen versammelte der Buddha die Gemeinde. 402
a2-3 Am Morgen nahm er [scil. der Buddha] Almosenschale [und] Gewand [und] trat in Śrāvastī den Almosen[gang] an. Nach dem Essen nahm er seine Sitzmatte [und] ging in den Andhava-Wald, um in Meditation zu sitzen. 399-400
a4-5 Der Buddha breitete sich [seine] Sitzmatte unter einem [wtl. irgendeinem] Baum aus [und] setzte sich. Auch Kāḷodāyin breitete sich [seine] Sitzmatte von gleicher Größe(?) unter einem [wtl. irgendeinem] Baum aus [und] setzte sich. 436-7
a6-b1 Bei einer Sitzgelegenheit [ist] von dem Mönch, der [sie] anfertigt, nach Maß zu verfahren. Hier [wtl. da] ist das Maß: In der Länge zwei Spannen entsprechend der Spanne des Buddha, in der Breite anderthalb [Spannen] für die Fransen eine Spanne. Macht er mehr als das, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika-Vergehen. 426
b3-4 Er [scil. Nanda] machte sich ein dem Gewand des Buddha gleiches Gewand. 425
b3f Er machte sich ein dem Gewand des Buddha gleiches Gewand. 80
b4-5 Wenn sich aber ein Mönch [wtl. welcher Mönch] ein Gewand nach dem Maß des Gewandes des Buddha oder über das Buddhagewand hinaus macht, [so ist das] ein Pātayantika[-Vergehen]. 425


TEKST OGI nog niet vergeleken


Translation according to [[Broomhead I]]: 71-72:

a1 invited (pl.): After eating Buddha gathered together the community [and] reprimanded this matter: "On a blanket belonging to the community a monk shall neither cepille or lie, [if he is] eñatketse.

a2 He ordered a bed to be made. Buddha tarried in Śrāvasti [and] in the morning he [took his] alms-bowl [and] robe [and] entered [and] begged for alms in Śrāvasti.

a3 After the meal he took [his] mat [and] went into the Andhava-grove in order to meditate. The worthy Kāḷodāyin

a4 followed the Buddha. Buddha spread out his mat beneath a tree [and] sat down. Kāḷodāyin also spread out his mat oppīläṃntsa under the tree

a5 [and] sat down. The latter (Kāḷodāyin) was large of body [and] touched the ground with both [his] knees. Thereupon he said. "Oh, may the Buddha order a mat

a6 to be made a span broader from the border!" When ordering a mat to be made, a monk shall have it made according to measure as follows:- This is the [correct] measurement.

b1 In length two spans, corresponding to the span of the Buddha, in width (= across) one and a half spans [and an extra] span for the borders. Should he make [it] more than this [then there is] a pāyti-sin. Buddha

b2 tarried in Kapilavāstu. Every time when Buddha's brother, called Nanda, entered the community the monks were doubtful [and confused] [and] of divided opinion. "Has Buddha

b3 or Nanda [just] entered?" Nanda had two main characteristics less than Buddha [and] was four fingers' breadth shorter than Buddha. [He] had had

b4 a robe similar to that of the Buddha made. Buddha heard [of this] [and] gathered together the community. Then he established this rule. "Whichever monk

b5 has a robe made of the same size as the Buddha's or over and above the [size of the] Buddha's robe [commits] a pāyti-sin. Here then is the size of the Buddha's robe.

b6 In length nine spans corresponding to the span of the Buddha, in width six [spans]. This is then the size of the Buddha's robe.


[[Broomhead I]]: 72-73 contains further notes on text and translation.
A parallel text is found in [[IOL Toch 210]], cf. also [[IOL Toch 396]].
According to [[Broomhead I]]: 70, "in a very good state of preservation. Written in medium sized ductus".

a1 – kākauwa • śeśuwer pos_t_aṃ pañäkte sāṅ kraupāte • ce_u\ w[ä]ntare nāksate [– s]·ṅkik raktsisa ṣam·nentse • eñatketse [m]· ceppi·[l]· a2 mā wsa_ṣ_ṣ_alle • prastrāṃ yātka yāmtsi • || pañäkte śrāvastine _m_askīt_r_a • tsoṅkai_k\• pātrai wastsi kamāte śrāvastine piṃtwāt yopsa • a3 śeśuwer pos_t_aṃ • niṣīdaṃ ○ kamāte andhavaṃ warttone masa ompalskoññe lamatsi • śaulassu kāḷodāye pañäkte o- a4 -mpos_t_aṃ masa • pañäkte a○lye_k_a kca stām ño_r\ niṣīdaṃ raksate lyama • kāḷodāye rano alye_k_a kca stām ñor oppī_l_aṃ- a5 -ntsa niṣīdaṃ raksate lyama • su no orotse kektsentsa • antapi kenīsa keṃ teksa • tumeṃ weña au • watkaṣṣi pi pañäkte niṣīdaṃ a6 ñremeṃ _k_alymi raso tsamtsi • || lamallesa ṣamānentsa yamaskemanesa • yärmaṃssu yama_ṣ_alle • omte se yarmä _p_arkarñe- b1 -sa wi rsoñcä • pañäktentse rasosa • pkantesa śle ywārcä • ñret_s\ raso • tumeṃ oṃṣap yāmt_r_a • ī_p_aṣṣeñca || || pañäkte kapilavā- b2 -stune _m_askīt_r_a • pañäktentse proce_r\• nānde ñe_m\ • kr_ui sāṅne yapi sklokacci ṣamāni ywārcä _m_askīyent_r_a • pañäkte wat yopsa b3 nānde wa_t\ • wi lakṣānä○ñcä • pañäktemeṃ nandentse meṅki ṣeṃ • śtwāra praroṃ pañäktemeṃ meṅki ṣai • pañäktentse wastsi- b4 -mpa sā_m\ • wastsi yamaṣṣi○t_r_a • pañäkte klyauṣa sāṅ kraupāte • ce śikṣapā_t\ śānmya • || _m_aksu no ṣamāne • pañäktentse b5 wästsintse yarmtsa wastsi yamīt_r_a • oṃṣṣap wa_t\ pañä_k_t_aññe wästsimeṃ • ī_p_aṣṣeñca • omte te pañäktentse wästsintse yarmä • b6 _p_arkarññesa ñu rsonta • pañä_k_t_aññe rasosa • pkantesa ṣka_s\ • te om[·]e pañäktentse wästsint[s]e yarmä • 90 || weweñuwa ñä –

div.p:
TEKST OGI nog niet vergeleken

Translation according to <citedRange>71-72</citedRange></bibl>: </p><p>a1 invited (pl.): After eating Buddha gathered together the community [and] reprimanded this matter: "On a blanket belonging to the community a monk shall neither cepille or lie, [if he is] eñatketse. </p><p>a2 He ordered a bed to be made. Buddha tarried in Śrāvasti [and] in the morning he [took his] alms-bowl [and] robe [and] entered [and] begged for alms in Śrāvasti. </p><p>a3 After the meal he took [his] mat [and] went into the Andhava-grove in order to meditate. The worthy Kāḷodāyin </p><p>a4 followed the Buddha. Buddha spread out his mat beneath a tree [and] sat down. Kāḷodāyin also spread out his mat oppīläṃntsa under the tree </p><p>a5 [and] sat down. The latter (Kāḷodāyin) was large of body [and] touched the ground with both [his] knees. Thereupon he said. "Oh, may the Buddha order a mat </p><p>a6 to be made a span broader from the border!" When ordering a mat to be made, a monk shall have it made according to measure as follows:- This is the [correct] measurement. </p><p>b1 In length two spans, corresponding to the span of the Buddha, in width (= across) one and a half spans [and an extra] span for the borders. Should he make [it] more than this [then there is] a pāyti-sin. Buddha </p><p>b2 tarried in Kapilavāstu. Every time when Buddha's brother, called Nanda, entered the community the monks were doubtful [and confused] [and] of divided opinion. "Has Buddha </p><p>b3 or Nanda [just] entered?" Nanda had two main characteristics less than Buddha [and] was four fingers' breadth shorter than Buddha. [He] had had </p><p>b4 a robe similar to that of the Buddha made. Buddha heard [of this] [and] gathered together the community. Then he established this rule. "Whichever monk </p><p>b5 has a robe made of the same size as the Buddha's or over and above the [size of the] Buddha's robe [commits] a pāyti-sin. Here then is the size of the Buddha's robe. </p><p>b6 In length nine spans corresponding to the span of the Buddha, in width six [spans]. This is then the size of the Buddha's robe. </p><p><bibl><title corresp="ref:broomhead1962"/><citedRange>72-73</citedRange></bibl> contains further notes on text and translation.</p></project_comment>
